Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
CyberWorkshops: Resources and Strategies for Teaching Cybersecurity in Computer Science (CReST)

This project is a collaboration between Tennessee Tech University and Towson University. The project team will address cybersecurity workforce issues by improving faculty expertise in cybersecurity. This will be accomplished by a series of workshops for computer science faculty that will be taught by cybersecurity faculty. The workshops will provide faculty with teaching resources and prepare them to incorporate cybersecurity concepts into their courses. The project will be funded by the Division of Graduate Education through the Cybercorps:SFS program.

Modelled after the successful Tapestry project for high school CS teachers (developed at the University of Virginia), through a series of workshops across the nation, the project team will develop a community of trainers (faculty in cybersecurity) with skills and resources to organize professional development workshops for computer science faculty. CReST workshop participants and cybersecurity faculty will share security integration strategies, research-based practices, and field-tested security resources. In the context of this project, workshops will focus on dissemination of course materials developed as part of the Security Injections @ Towson and the SecKnitKit projects. The project will also facilitate dissemination of other effective security educational resources developed by security faculty across nation. The direct effect will build a community among CS faculty teaching security and significantly increase faculty awareness and understanding of secure coding concepts. This will lead to an increase in the number of students with cybersecurity knowledge and skills, increase student ability to apply secure coding principles , and increase student awareness of security issues in core computer science subject matters such as software engineering, database, networks and operating systems. Project evaluation will include pre-workshop and post-workshop surveys, workshop observations, and aggregation across all workshop participants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CReST (CyberWorkshops: Resources and Strategies for Teaching Cybersecurity in Computer Science) project built upon the success of several cybersecurity education projects and used the experience of leaders in the cybersecurity education community to launch a series of cyber workshops across the nation to develop faculty expertise in cybersecurity, arm faculty with cybersecurity teaching resources, and build a community of cybersecurity educators. CReST Workshop participants included faculty from two-year and four-year institutions teaching both security and non-security courses in computer science. Using a well-honed workshop model, which included successful security integration strategies, incentives to initiate and sustain adoption, research-based practices, and provides a wealth of field-tested teaching resources from effective projects, CReST has been empowering CS faculty to teach cybersecurity and have a lasting impact on cybersecurity education.

Security integration is well-recognized as vital to comprehensive security education and significant work has been done to develop a library of cybersecurity resources to be used across all computer science courses. The CReST project provided the next essential step towards transforming security education by launching a series of cyber-workshops across the nation to develop faculty expertise in cybersecurity, armed them with cybersecurity teaching resources, and helped to build a community of cybersecurity educators. By incorporating several effective cybersecurity education materials that targeted the entire undergraduate program (through Security Injections and Security Knitting Kit Projects), this project helped to ensure that students are taught security principles from the first course. By using a workshop model that involved faculty as the source of change, CReST has helped to increase the number of faculty who require their students to practice security.

Over the course of three years, CReST has organized four faculty development workshops for around 50 faculty participants, majority of who had no prior teaching experience in security, their curriculum did not offer any mandatory security courses but they had an interest in integrating security traditional CS courses. In addition to these two day workshops, CReST also offered 4 mini-CReST workshops at various CS conferences that reached around 80 faculty with majority of them from underrepresented groups. While our initial proposal aimed to provide professional development for around 130 faculty, at the time of grant award, the budget was cut down in half (approximately) to target around 80 faculty. Half of these faculty received stipends from WiCyS project (NSF Award#1303441). In all, over the course of the CReST project, we have offered (and scheduled to offer) professional development to over 130 faculty participants with the reduced budget. Faculty were given training on using Security Knitting Kit (SecKnitKit: NSF Award#1140864 ) project material in four traditional CS courses, which are Software Engineering, Operating Systems, Computer Networks, and Database Management Systems. Overall, evaluations show non-security faculty reported significant gains in knowledge, awareness, and interest related to computer security in the wide variety of areas addressed by the SecKnitKit.

This project helped in creating a security mindset in computer science faculty and empowered them to include important security topics that may otherwise be unfamiliar. CReST faculty workshops enhanced the dissemination and broader impacts of several NSF funded projects (Security Knitting Kit, Security Injections, SEED, EDURange, and ITSEED). We have reached over 130 faculty from diverse institutions across the nation who will transform cybersecurity education and increase the number of undergraduate students recognizing the importance of security. This will provide computer science graduates with the appropriate skill set to meet the national need for a cybersecurity workforce.
